ygData.msgSnippet: Hi all, We talked a bit about the format for run XML a while back, but we re running into the issue of network (or phenotype) XML. We ve revamped our neural

X-Yahoo-Profile: blue5432

Hi all,

We talked a bit about the format for run XML a while
back, but we're running into the issue of network (or
phenotype) XML.

We've revamped our neural network framework to more
logically work with NEAT, and basically there is no
concept of layers in a NEAT phenotype (other than
input and output).  We have graphical tools that lay
out our raw chromosome XML in a spiral pattern, but
while it looks kind of cool, it isn't very readable.

So if we have a network, evolved with NEAT, that has
10 input nodes, 10 output nodes, and 35 hidden nodes,
with dozens of connections (self, recurrent, and
forward), how does it make the most sense to:

--Represent this phenotype in XML?
--Graphically represent this phenotype?

Here's a current sample of our XML:

<neuron id="1" type="IN"/>
<neuron id="2" type="IN"/>
<neuron id="7" type="HIDDEN"/>
<neuron id="3" type="OUT"/>
<connection id="4" src-id="0" dest-id="3"
weight="-1.3731676929130425"/>
<connection id="5" src-id="1" dest-id="3"
weight="-1.208831769841949"/>
<connection id="6" src-id="2" dest-id="3"
weight="-0.853548931074944"/>

Should the neuron tags also include an attribute
assigning them to a particular layer?  We use XSL to
parse the XML into SVG, and in and of itself, XSL
really isn't useful for determining layout logic. 
It's best to have the layout structure inherent in the
XML.

Thoughts?

Derek
